articles.headline: Tax Gap Puts Private Equity Firms on Hot Seat
articles.snippet: A tax law quirk allows private equity firms to operate as partnerships and to pay lower tax rates than corporations.
articles.abstract: A tax law quirk allows private equity firms to operate as partnerships and to pay lower tax rates than corporations.
articles.lead_paragraph: This week, Goldman Sachs, Wall Street’s most profitable firm, reported that it earned about $3.4 billion for the second quarter. As always, it set aside a big chunk of money  $1.1 billion, or about 32 percent  to pay corporate income taxes on its healthy profits.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Facing Sanction, Duke Prosecutor Plans to Resign
articles.snippet: At a disciplinary hearing, Michael B. Nifong apologized to three lacrosse players and their families.
articles.abstract: At a disciplinary hearing, Michael B. Nifong apologized to three lacrosse players and their families.
articles.lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C., June 15 —Michael B. Nifong, the Durham County district attorney, announced Friday that he would resign, as he faces disciplinary charges for his handling of a sexual assault prosecution against three former Duke University lacrosse players who were later declared innocent.

articles.headline: Pests That Bite and Slither? Call Snake Wranglers
articles.snippet: In Los Angeles, a drought has increased business for people who enjoy removing snakes from the property of others.
articles.abstract: In Los Angeles, a drought has increased business for people who enjoy removing snakes from the property of others.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, June 14  For Sam the Weimaraner, things had been quite grave. A rattlesnake bite to the snout  the unhappy result of flower bed pursuit  had left him unconscious, lying in his owner’s garage in Topanga Canyon, an IV dangling from his paw.

articles.headline: In Aftermath of Gaza Battle, Grim Realities
articles.snippet: People in Gaza worried about how a round of deadly infighting postponed hope for an independent and unified Palestinian state.
articles.abstract: People in Gaza worried about how a round of deadly infighting postponed hope for an independent and unified Palestinian state.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA, June 15 — This packed, impoverished coastal strip had a postrevolutionary feel on Friday: the green flag of Hamas, victor over Fatah in what amounted to a five-day civil war, flew over public buildings where once the multicolored Palestinian one had been.
articles.byline: By Taghreed El-Khodary and Ian Fisher

articles.headline: With a Few Exceptions, the Advice Remains: Don’t Touch That Nest Egg
articles.snippet: Most Americans have enough difficulty building up a nest egg, and cracking it prematurely could mean living on Social Security later.
articles.abstract: Most Americans have enough difficulty building up a nest egg, and cracking it prematurely could mean living on Social Security later.
articles.lead_paragraph: Conventional wisdom says not to pull money out of retirement accounts except for actual retirement. Most Americans have enough difficulty building up a nest egg, and cracking it prematurely could mean living on cat food (slang for Social Security) later.

articles.headline: Polished and Upbeat, Romney Tries to Connect
articles.snippet: Some people who have seen Mitt Romney at recent events say he is impressive but somewhat detached.
articles.abstract: Some people who have seen Mitt Romney at recent events say he is impressive but somewhat detached.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa — Mitt Romney loves the word “great.” As in, “Have a great day,” “Things are going great,” “I’m feeling great.” Mr. Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, also looks great, sounds great and smells great, like shaving cream. Everyone who asks him something gets a “Thanks, great question.”

articles.headline: Cost of Gas and Food Rose Sharply Last Month
articles.snippet: Americans faced higher gas prices and eroding wages, even as an important gauge of inflation drifted lower.
articles.abstract: Americans faced higher gas prices and eroding wages, even as an important gauge of inflation drifted lower.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans felt the pinch of higher gas prices and eroding wages last month, even as an important gauge of inflation drifted lower, government figures showed yesterday.

articles.headline: Globalization in Every Loaf
articles.snippet: The lowering of trade barriers has pushed food companies to scour the globe for the cheapest ingredients to compete in a global marketplace.
articles.abstract: The lowering of trade barriers has pushed food companies to scour the globe for the cheapest ingredients to compete in a global marketplace.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOWNERS GROVE, Ill.  In a glassed-off area in the headquarters of Sara Lee, a handful of specialists study computer screens and flat-screen televisions beaming the latest weather reports and commodity prices. They are sourcing ingredients from all over the world to make Sara Lee’s assortment of breads, deli meats and microwaveable desserts.

articles.headline: Can a Vision Save All of Africa?
articles.snippet: Some economists say that while Jeffrey Sachs means well, he is peddling a dream that will always be just that: a dream.
articles.abstract: Some economists say that while Jeffrey Sachs means well, he is peddling a dream that will always be just that: a dream.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was “Malaria in Africa Week” here in New York. Not officially, of course. But by coincidence, two big malaria-related events took place that were by turns moving, inspiring and invigorating.

articles.headline: Web Help for Getting Mortgage the Criminal Way
articles.snippet: New Web sites have helped fuel the rampant mortgage fraud that has caused a huge spike in loan defaults.
articles.abstract: New Web sites have helped fuel the rampant mortgage fraud that has caused a huge spike in loan defaults.
articles.lead_paragraph: Want to buy a home, but hampered by bad credit, an empty bank account or no job? No problem!

articles.headline: Yes, the Screen Is Tiny, but the Plans Are Big
articles.snippet: After some hits and misses in creating content for cellphones, ESPN thinks it knows how to keep up with its fans as they go about their days.
articles.abstract: After some hits and misses in creating content for cellphones, ESPN thinks it knows how to keep up with its fans as they go about their days.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bristol, Conn.

articles.headline: Hear Ye, Hear Ye: Corralling Executive Pay
articles.snippet: A group of investors argues that an analysis of a company’s pay practices can provide insights into managerial confidence.
articles.abstract: A group of investors argues that an analysis of a company’s pay practices can provide insights into managerial confidence.
articles.lead_paragraph: EXAMINING insider stock transactions has always helped investors gauge managers’ confidence in their own company’s prospects. Shareholders who hear an executive boast of a grand strategic plan while dumping piles of his own stock have a right to be dubious. Actions speak louder than words, after all.

articles.headline: Online Sales Lose Steam
articles.snippet: Online commerce has enjoyed hypergrowth, but now that growth has slowed sharply.
articles.abstract: Online commerce has enjoyed hypergrowth, but now that growth has slowed sharply.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, June 16 — Has online retailing entered the Dot Calm era?
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Bob Tedeschi

articles.headline: Palestinian Split Poses a Policy Quandary for U.S.
articles.snippet: Israel and the U.S. seem agreed to boost Fatah in the West Bank and squeeze Hamas in Gaza, but there are pitfalls.
articles.abstract: Israel and the U.S. seem agreed to boost Fatah in the West Bank and squeeze Hamas in Gaza, but there are pitfalls.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM, June 16 — With the two Palestinian territories increasingly isolated from each other by a week of brutal warfare between rival factions, Israel and the United States seem agreed on a policy to treat them as separate entities to support Fatah in the West Bank and squeeze Hamas in the Gaza Strip.

articles.headline: G.I.’s in Iraq Open Big Offensive Against Al Qaeda
articles.snippet: The push comes at a critical time, with increasing U.S. casualties and rising pressure to show results or begin troop withdrawals.
articles.abstract: The push comes at a critical time, with increasing U.S. casualties and rising pressure to show results or begin troop withdrawals.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, June 16 — With the influx of tens of thousands of additional combat troops into Iraq now complete, American forces have begun a wide offensive against Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia on the outskirts of Baghdad, the top American commander in Iraq said Saturday.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Can You Be Too Fashionable?
articles.snippet: The Kohl’s department store chain intends to make Vera Wang, best known as a designer of exquisite and often very expensive bridal gowns, the public face of its reinvention.
articles.abstract: The Kohl’s department store chain intends to make Vera Wang, best known as a designer of exquisite and often very expensive bridal gowns, the public face of its reinvention.
articles.lead_paragraph: STANDING with her back to a room full of Kohl’s department store executives in a Manhattan studio, Vera Wang reviewed prototypes from an exclusive new collection of mainstream fashion that Kohl’s plans to sell under her name. “This is all black,” said Ms. Wang, dismissively. “Black is very ’90s.”
articles.byline: By Eric Wilson and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Among Firefighters in New York, Mixed Views on Giuliani
articles.snippet: Some firefighters resent the way the former mayor treated the department before and after Sept. 11.
articles.abstract: Some firefighters resent the way the former mayor treated the department before and after Sept. 11.
articles.lead_paragraph: Their images are permanently etched in photographs after the fall of the World Trade Center towers, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and firefighters cloaked in the same gray dust. For months afterward, they stood together at funerals. Mr. Giuliani, in his eulogy, always asked for a round of applause to celebrate the dead firefighter’s life.

articles.headline: Here to Take Your Order (and Biting Their Tongues)
articles.snippet: American waitresses take pride in doing work that they realize many people, including some they serve so diligently, put them down for doing at all.
articles.abstract: American waitresses take pride in doing work that they realize many people, including some they serve so diligently, put them down for doing at all.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE groans were increasing.

articles.headline: Erasing Tattoos, Out of Regret or for a New Canvas
articles.snippet: A growing industry caters to people who may not have thought about the implications of “forever” the first time.
articles.abstract: A growing industry caters to people who may not have thought about the implications of “forever” the first time.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Kelly Brannigan was suffering from a case of tattoo remorse.

articles.headline: Airbus Hopes Its Planes, Not Its Setbacks, Will Stand Out
articles.snippet: It is the twin-engine A350, not the delayed and much-publicized A380 superjumbo, that Airbus hopes will grab headlines at the Paris air show.
articles.abstract: It is the twin-engine A350, not the delayed and much-publicized A380 superjumbo, that Airbus hopes will grab headlines at the Paris air show.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, June 17 — The A380 superjumbo, swooping high above Le Bourget airfield during its daily demonstration flights, may cast a long shadow over the Paris air show this year. Production delays for the much-publicized 555-seat A380, have been the catalyst for Airbus’s outsize woes over the last year.
articles.byline: By Nicola Clark and Leslie Wayne

articles.headline: In Ethiopia, Fear and Cries of Army Brutality
articles.snippet: At the epicenter of a war pitting nomads against one of the biggest armies in Africa, villagers said they had been brutalized by government troops.
articles.abstract: At the epicenter of a war pitting nomads against one of the biggest armies in Africa, villagers said they had been brutalized by government troops.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN THE OGADEN DESERT, Ethiopia — The rebels march 300 strong across the crunchy earth, young men with dreadlocks and AK-47s slung over their shoulders.

articles.headline: Marvel Wants to Flex Its Own Heroic Muscles as a Moviemaker
articles.snippet: No longer content to leave the actual moviemaking to the studios, the newly minted chairman of Marvel Studios is able to green-light movies of his choosing.
articles.abstract: No longer content to leave the actual moviemaking to the studios, the newly minted chairman of Marvel Studios is able to green-light movies of his choosing.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, June 17 — This month David Maisel, the newly minted chairman of Marvel Studios, was discussing plot points in his Beverly Hills office with Edward Norton, the Academy Award-nominated actor whom he has cast as the star of a new version of “The Incredible Hulk.”

articles.headline: Taking On Big Donors, McCain Takes a Big Risk
articles.snippet: Senator John McCain’s campaign may be paying the price for a career of positions alienating traditional big donors.
articles.abstract: Senator John McCain’s campaign may be paying the price for a career of positions alienating traditional big donors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 17 — A ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee like Senator John McCain could normally bank on a bonanza of campaign contributions from the defense industry, especially if he was under pressure to raise money fast.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Michael Cooper

articles.headline: After Bus Attack, Afghan Police Mourn Their Own
articles.snippet: A mammoth explosion tore through a police bus in the heart of Kabul on Sunday, killing at least 24 people — 22 of them police academy instructors on their way to work.
articles.abstract: A mammoth explosion tore through a police bus in the heart of Kabul on Sunday, killing at least 24 people — 22 of them police academy instructors on their way to work.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 17 — A mammoth explosion tore through a police bus in the heart of Kabul on Sunday morning, killing at least 24 people — 22 of them police academy instructors on their way to work — in one of the deadliest insurgent attacks in Afghanistan since the fall of the Taliban in 2001.

articles.headline: Restaurant Reservations Go Online
articles.snippet: After decades of relying on telephones to book tables, the restaurant business has gone high-tech.
articles.abstract: After decades of relying on telephones to book tables, the restaurant business has gone high-tech.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, June 17 — Town Hall, one of the busiest restaurants in this food-crazed city, seems the very model of old-fashioned dining. Patrons who arrive to claim their reserved seats are greeted by a hostess who consults a piece of paper with the day’s reservations and leads her guests to the appointed table.

articles.headline: New Capos’ Taut Smiles at HBO
articles.snippet: With the denouement of “The Sopranos” and the departure of former chief executive Chris Albrecht, HBO has a big case of the “now what’s?”
articles.abstract: With the denouement of “The Sopranos” and the departure of former chief executive Chris Albrecht, HBO has a big case of the “now what’s?”
articles.lead_paragraph: The keening that followed the 11 seconds of inky blackness at the end of “The Sopranos” finale has finally begun to die down. But the executives at HBO could be forgiven for feeling like they are still staring into that dark place.

articles.headline: Autism Debate Strains a Family and Its Charity
articles.snippet: Fissures in the autism community over the cause of the disorder have made their way into the Wright family, founders of the charity Autism Speaks.
articles.abstract: Fissures in the autism community over the cause of the disorder have made their way into the Wright family, founders of the charity Autism Speaks.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year after their grandson Christian received a diagnosis of autism in 2004, Bob Wright, then chairman of NBC/Universal, and his wife, Suzanne, founded Autism Speaks, a mega-charity dedicated to curing the dreaded neurological disorder that affects one of every 150 children in America today.
articles.byline: By Jane Gross and Stephanie Strom

articles.headline: Retail Giant Will Remake Private Bank
articles.snippet: Bank of America will see if a new name, U.S. Trust, Bank of America Private Wealth Management, can burnish its private bank’s reputation in catering to the very rich.
articles.abstract: Bank of America will see if a new name, U.S. Trust, Bank of America Private Wealth Management, can burnish its private bank’s reputation in catering to the very rich.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank of America built its brand as a financial supermarket that could be all things to all people. Now, it will see if a new name can burnish its private bank's reputation in catering to the very rich.
